newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Zaire envoy denies South Africa talks.
newsitem.headline: Zaire envoy denies South Africa talks.

text.p: A senior Zairean politician in Cape Town denied on Thursday that he would hold talks with Zairean rebels despite South African indications that a peace initiative was on track.

"There has never been any question of meeting any member of the (Zairean) rebellion in South Africa," Ngbanda Nzambo Ko Ayumba, the nephew and chief security adviser of Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko told Radio France Internationale (RFI) in a telephone interview from Cape Town.
"I simply note that this morning a South African government statement specified that there was no plan for a meeting between a member of the government of Zaire and the rebels," he said.

South African President Nelson Mandela said on Wednesday his country would try to bring the two sides together in Cape Town on Thursday. A spokesman for Mandela said the peace initiative was on track but South Africa put a lid on all news.

"For us there are conditions, we want first of all the real people behind this aggression to show their goodwill and respect the decisions of the Security Council," Ngbanda said, referring to a U.N. call for all foreign forces to withdraw.

"We are being attacked by three neighbouring countries and we demand that the three neighbouring countries pull out their soldiers and let Zaireans find a solution to their internal problems," he added.
